question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Let $P(x)$ be a polynomial such that when $P(x)$ is divided by $x - 19,$ the remainder is 99, and when $P(x)$ is divided by $x - 99,$ the remainder is 19.  What is the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x - 19)(x - 99)$?
inference:
By the Polynomial Remainder Theorem, $P(19) = 99$ and $P(99) = 19.$  Let the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $(x - 19)(x - 99)$ be $ax + b.$  Then
\[P(x) = (x - 19)(x - 99) Q(x) + ax + b\]for some polynomial $Q(x).$  Setting $x = 19,$ we get
\[99 = 19a + b.\]Setting $x = 99,$ we get
\[19 = 99a + b.\]Solving, we find $a = -1$ and $b = 118,$ so the remainder is $\boxed{-x + 118}.$ 
Final Answer: $\boxed{-x + 118}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
By the Remainder Theorem, $P(19) = 99$ and $P(99) = 19.$

When $P(x)$ is divided by $(x - 19)(x - 99),$ the remainder must be of the form $ax + b.$  Thus,
\[P(x) = (x - 19)(x - 99) Q(x) + ax + b,\]for some polynomial $Q(x).$

Setting $x = 19$ and $x = 99,$ we get
\begin{align*}
19a + b &= P(19) = 99, \\
99a + b &= P(99) = 19.
\end{align*}Subtracting the equations, we get $80a = -80,$ so $a = -1.$  Then $-19 + b = 99,$ so $b = 118.$  Hence, the remainder is $\boxed{-x + 118}.$

ground_truth:
By the Remainder Theorem, $P(19) = 99$ and $P(99) = 19.$

When $P(x)$ is divided by $(x - 19)(x - 99),$ the remainder must be of the form $ax + b.$  Thus,
\[P(x) = (x - 19)(x - 99) Q(x) + ax + b,\]for some polynomial $Q(x).$

Setting $x = 19$ and $x = 99,$ we get
\begin{align*}
19a + b &= P(19) = 99, \\
99a + b &= P(99) = 19.
\end{align*}Subtracting the equations, we get $80a = -80,$ so $a = -1.$  Then $-19 + b = 99,$ so $b = 118.$  Hence, the remainder is $\boxed{-x + 118}.$
